issue.title: ipv6 disable but nextdns still listening?
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.38.0
 - Platform: void linux

I have disabled IPv6 on my system. Nextdns config:
```
config xxxxxx
discovery-dns
detect-captive-portals false
listen 0.0.0.0:53
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
log-queries true
hardened-privacy false
use-hosts true
auto-activate true
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
report-client-info true
mdns all
max-inflight-requests 256
max-ttl 5s
bogus-priv true
timeout 5s
setup-router true
```
(note: I specified `0.0.0.0` as the listen address as part of troubleshooting.)

`netstat -anop` shows
```
Active Internet connections (servers and established)
Proto Recv-Q Send-Q Local Address           Foreign Address         State       PID/Program name     Timer
tcp        0      0 192.168.1.102:38596     170.39.224.134:443      ESTABLISHED 269/nextdns          keepalive (9.78/0/0)
tcp6       0      0 :::53                   :::*                    LISTEN      269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
udp        0      0 0.0.0.0:5353            0.0.0.0:*                           269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
udp6       0      0 :::53                   :::*                                269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
udp6       0      0 :::5353                 :::*                                269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
````

Is there a way to get nextdns to stop binding to (nonexistent) ipv6?

`ip a`:
```
1: lo: <LOOPBACK,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 65536 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN group default qlen 1000
    link/loopback 00:00:00:00:00:00 brd 00:00:00:00:00:00
    inet 127.0.0.1/8 scope host lo
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
113: eth0@if114: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc noqueue state UP group default qlen 1000
    link/ether 00:16:3e:44:9b:a4 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff link-netnsid 0
    inet 192.168.1.102/24 brd 192.168.1.255 scope global eth0
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
```

comment.body: Yes, setup-router will ignore the provided listen directive and use a value appropriate for the detected router. I missed that you had that on.

`netstat -anop` shows
```
Active Internet connections (servers and established)
Proto Recv-Q Send-Q Local Address           Foreign Address         State       PID/Program name     Timer
tcp        0      0 192.168.1.102:38596     170.39.224.134:443      ESTABLISHED 269/nextdns          keepalive (9.78/0/0)
tcp6       0      0 :::53                   :::*                    LISTEN      269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
udp        0      0 0.0.0.0:5353            0.0.0.0:*                           269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)

udp6       0      0 :::5353                 :::*                                269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
````

Is there a way to get nextdns to stop binding to (nonexistent) ipv6?

`ip a`:
```
1: lo: <LOOPBACK,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 65536 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN group default qlen 1000
    link/loopback 00:00:00:00:00:00 brd 00:00:00:00:00:00
    inet 127.0.0.1/8 scope host lo
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
113: eth0@if114: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc noqueue state UP group default qlen 1000
    link/ether 00:16:3e:44:9b:a4 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff link-netnsid 0

       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever

comment.body: By using 0.0.0.0 you are explicitly asking the kernel to bind any interface. If you want to bind a specific interface IP, use it's IP instead.

issue.title: NextDNS CLI on Home Assistant!
issue.body:
Hello there!
Is there any way to implement nextdns-cli as Addon for Home Assistant?
This could be very useful for devices using Home Assistant OS, where it's not possible to install other programs.
As far as I know, the competitor AdGuard Home does provide an Addon for Home Assistant but this, configured for NextDNS, won't identify the devices on My NextDNS website.
Cheers!

issue.title: Add Prehook and Pretimestamp features: this allows "time" key come first
issue.body:
Multiple log files can be sorted with `sort` if "time" key comes first.
For example:

```
$ cat node1.log nod2.log node3.log | sort
{"time":"2022-08-06T08:02:01Z","level":"info","node":"node1","message":"foo"}
{"time":"2022-08-06T08:02:12Z","level":"info","node":"node2","message":"bar"}
{"time":"2022-08-06T08:03:03Z","level":"info","node":"node1","message":"bar"}
{"time":"2022-08-06T08:03:10Z","level":"info","node":"node3","message":"bar"}
...
```

It would be useful in environments where logs aren't managed with log managing systems like Google Cloud Logging, AWS CloudWatch, and so on.


What I did:

* I added `Prehook()` feature. It calls hooks just before "level" is added to the buffer.
* I added `Pretimestamp()` feature. It adds timestamp hook with `Prehook`.

comment.body: I'm not comfortable adding such complexity just for field ordering. I would recommend using tools to read JSON logs instead of dealing with raw output.

Move GPG key file for Debian in /etc/apt/keyrings (#756)

Maybe it would help with failed upgrades for Unifi as users are
reporting the file to disappear when placed in /usr/share/keyrings. We
apply the change for all Debian-derivative to avoid confusion.
/etc/apt/keyrings may even be a better location because
/usr/share/keyrings should only contain files installed from the package
manager.

May fix #755

issue.title: bogus-priv true returning SERVFAIL instead of NXDOMAIN causing pfSense DHCP leases page to hang
issue.body:
I have NextDNS CLI installed on my pfSense firewall, with Unbound resolver configured on an alternate port and discovery-dns and local forwarder configuration for my split-DNS domain pointing at that local Unbound instance. 

When activating NextDNS for answering local queries from pfSense itself, I noticed that the DHCP Leases page in the admin interface was hanging. I ultimately determined that this was being caused by retries on reverse DNS lookups of local IPs that were failing with a SERVFAIL response. If bogus-priv is set to false, then those reverse lookups that are not answered by local Unbound are forwarded up to NextDNS upstream but they now return an NXDOMAIN response as expected. 

The only other changes I've made from defaults that may be somewhat unique is that I've disabled mdns support as NextDNS's mdns client conflicts with the local Avahi instance I use for mdns reflection between subnets. I've also disabled use-hosts as that was returning duplicate A record responses when local unbound and hosts file both contain an entry (pfSense puts all local host overrides both in the /etc/hosts file and in the local Unbound config as local-data entries). use-hosts was also not allowing AAAA queries for entries in /etc/hosts to fall through to DNS upstream or local Unbound via the forwarder entry. (I have unbound set up with "typetransparent" zone type to enable exactly this behavior).

**NextDNS version: 1.37.11**

Redacted config:

```
hardened-privacy false
bogus-priv false
use-hosts false
max-inflight-requests 256
setup-router false
forwarder redacted-domain.com.=127.0.0.1:5555
log-queries false
discovery-dns 127.0.0.1:5555
mdns disabled
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
config 10.70.6.0/23=GUEST-CONFIG-ID
config MAIN-CONFIG-ID
max-ttl 5s
report-client-info true
timeout 5s
auto-activate true
listen 0.0.0.0:53
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
detect-captive-portals false
```

Demonstrating the issue:

With bogus-priv set to false:

```
: dig @127.0.0.1 -x 10.10.10.10

; <<>> DiG 9.16.26 <<>> @127.0.0.1 -x 10.10.10.10
; (1 server found)
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NXDOMAIN, id: 36858
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 0, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 1

;; OPT PSEUDOSECTION:
; EDNS: version: 0, flags:; udp: 1232
;; QUESTION SECTION:
;10.10.10.10.in-addr.arpa.	IN	PTR

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
10.in-addr.arpa.	5	IN	SOA	prisoner.iana.org. hostmaster.root-servers.org. 1 604800 60 604800 604800

;; Query time: 5 msec
;; SERVER: 127.0.0.1#53(127.0.0.1)
;; WHEN: Sun Oct 30 18:09:54 EDT 2022
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 130
```

bogus-priv set to true

```
: dig @127.0.0.1 -x 10.10.10.10

; <<>> DiG 9.16.26 <<>> @127.0.0.1 -x 10.10.10.10
; (1 server found)
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: SERVFAIL, id: 44584
;; flags: qr; QUERY: 0, ANSWER: 0, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; Query time: 0 msec
;; SERVER: 127.0.0.1#53(127.0.0.1)
;; WHEN: Sun Oct 30 18:10:50 EDT 2022
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 12
```

Nov 11 13:19:51.738295 WARN ...

pull_request.title: Add global ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField to reverse stack and error order
pull_request.body:
Stacktrace is enabled, and the output gets like this:

```
{"level":"error","stack":[{"func":"inner","line":"20","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"middle","line":"24","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"outer","line":"32","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"15","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"204","source":"proc.go"},{"func":"goexit","line":"1374","source":"asm_amd64.s"}],"error":"seems we have an error here","time":1609086683}
```

`"stack"` is often long and `"error"` comes to the later part of the log line.
I have difficulties for this behavior when using with datadog (https://www.datadoghq.com/): datadog sends error logs to monitoring devices (like mobile phone), but those logs are truncated with the beginning part of logs. Those logs are filled with stacktrace and I cannot see the most important "error" field there.

This pull request introduces `zerolog.ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField`.
Setting `zerolog.ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField = true` results log output like this:
```
{"level":"error","error":"seems we have an error here","stack":[{"func":"inner","line":"20","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"middle","line":"24","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"outer","line":"32","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"15","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"204","source":"proc.go"},{"func":"goexit","line":"1374","source":"asm_amd64.s"}],"time":1609086683}
```
You can find the error message easily.

commits.message: Fix docs and behavior of WithContext (#499)

issue.title: Invalid condition in WithContext method.
issue.body:
Since non-pointer receivers are passed **_by value_**, once the receiver for `WithContext` was reverted to a non-pointer, [this condition](https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/89617ff99b2feb29ab2d8b6258fac9d671073792/ctx.go#L30) is guaranteed to always be false.

In other words, the receiver (`l`) is a _copy_ of the Logger struct from the caller and its address can never be the same as the logger attached to the `Context`. 

Either the receiver should be converted back to a pointer (and different fixes devised for #116 and #400) -- or, this condition should simply be removed and the docs updated to say that the Context will always be replaced no matter what (because that's the actual behavior with the current logic).

[Here's a [Go Playground link](https://go.dev/play/p/Abw-heqUhwP) proving that non-pointer receivers have different addresses from those of their caller]

pull_request.title: Fix docs and behavior of WithContext
pull_request.body:
This change updates `WithContext` to better match documented behavior and also updates the documentation to both clarify existing behavior as well as the behavior expected by existing tests.

Note: since `WithContext` no longer employs a pointer receiver, the value comparison against the Context's attached logger value must be done via `reflect.DeepEqual`.

Fixes: #498

commits.message:
ConsoleWriter fallbacks to local timezone for missing TZ indicator (#497)

Closes issue #483

Before:
We use time.Parse which defaults to TZ UTC if there is no time zone
indicator specified in the time layout string. During the reparsing in
ConsoleWriter we therefore added the TZ difference to UTC twice.

After:
We use time.ParseInLocal where we need to provide a dedicated fallback
TZ as a fallback. Since we now fallback to the local TZ, we don't add
the TZ difference to UTC twice.

pull_request.title: ConsoleWriter fallbacks to local timezone for missing TZ indicator
pull_request.body:
Closes issue #483

Before:
We use time.Parse which defaults to TZ UTC if there is no time zone indicator specified in the time layout string. During the reparsing in ConsoleWriter we therefore added the TZ difference to UTC twice.

After:
We use time.ParseInLocal where we need to provide a dedicated fallback TZ as a fallback. Since we now fallback to the local TZ, we don't add the TZ difference to UTC twice.

issue.title: The time value is wrong when outputting the log to console.
issue.body:
**Code**：

```
package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"os"
	"time"

	"github.com/rs/zerolog"
	"github.com/rs/zerolog/log"
)

func main() {
	timeFormat := "2006-01-02 15:04:05"

	t := time.Now()
	fmt.Print("local zone: ")
	fmt.Println(t.Local().Zone())
	fmt.Println("def:", t.Format(timeFormat))
	fmt.Println("loc:", t.Local().Format(timeFormat))
	fmt.Println("utc:", t.UTC().Format(timeFormat))

	zerolog.TimeFieldFormat = timeFormat
	log.Print("hello world")

	log.Logger = log.Output(zerolog.ConsoleWriter{Out: os.Stderr, TimeFormat: timeFormat})
	log.Info().Msg("Wrong time")
}
```


**Output**:

> local zone: CST 28800
> def: 2022-09-23 21:19:29
> loc: 2022-09-23 21:19:29
> utc: 2022-09-23 13:19:29
> {"level":"debug","time":"2022-09-23 21:19:29","message":"hello world"}
> **2022-09-24 05:19:29** INF Wrong time

The local time is **2022-09-23 21:19:29** and the UTC time is **2022-09-23 13:19:29**, but the console output time is **2022-09-24 05:19:29** .
This issue is caused by #415 .

comment.body: I'm fine with a local tz default on console writer.

commits.message:
Adding Event.Type(...) method to log the type of an object (#437)

Co-authored-by: Mario Cormier <mcormier@rossvideo.com>

pull_request.title: Adding Event.Type(...) method to log the type of an object
pull_request.body:
I found myself wanting to log the type of an object and was convinced there would be a method to do that already, but I didn't find one.  Here's a case where one might want such a method:

```go
	var value interface{}
	var result string
	switch v := value.(type) {
	case int:
		result = strconv.Itoa(v)
	case string:
		result = v
	default:
		log.Panic().Type("type", v).Msg("Unexpected value type")
	}
	log.Info().Msg(result)
```

Let me know if there's anything else that needs to change for this to get accepted.

issue.title: nextdns stops running often
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.11
 - Platform: Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS 4.15.0-70-generic  

**Description**

I have a bash script (https://github.com/mbierman/Firewalla-NextDNS-CLI-install/blob/main/nextdnstest.sh) I run every 5 minutes to make sure that nextdns is installed and running using

```sudo nextdns status ```

If status is not, "running" then  it restarts nextdns and 15 seconds later it tries again. Most of the time that keeps things running without much noticeably wrong.  But it seems like one shouldn't have to be checking this often.

As you can see in the attached log, many times a day it fails. The number of tries listed shows how many loops required before nextdns reports "running" 

Other users are seeing similar things as covered in [this forum post](https://help.nextdns.io/t/g9h78dq/lot-of-disconnections-nextdns-cli-has-to-be-reinstalled-every-2-days). 

[nextdns.log](https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/files/9671612/nextdns.log)

comment.body: What do you get in `journalctl -ef` while this happen?

issue.title: `nextdns config list` didn't exactly match the running config, when using config file
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.10
 - Platform: Ubuntu 20.04.4 LTS with kernel 5.4.0-105-generic

**Problem:** NextDNS cli client didn't show the config file as expected. The config ID and other configs are specified in the config file, but `nextdns config list` didn't see it.

The NextDNS client was installed via the Debian Based Distribution Manual Install method mentioned on wiki: 
- https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/wiki/Debian-Based-Distribution#manual-install


The NextDNS service was installed by the command:

```sh
sudo nextdns install -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```


The content of `/opt/nextdns/config` is actually the result from a previous config, dump via the command `sudo nextdns config list`(the config ID was replaced by `xxxxxx`):
```
discovery-dns 
max-inflight-requests 512
auto-activate false
mdns all
detect-captive-portals false
bogus-priv true
use-hosts false
timeout 5s
listen localhost:53
log-queries false
report-client-info true
hardened-privacy false
config xxxxxx
max-ttl 0s
setup-router true
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
```

The additional manual setting here is: `cache-size 10MB`

I can confirmed that the option `-config-file /opt/nextdns/config` is set in the service file, andhe process is also running with the parameter::

`$ cat /etc/systemd/system/nextdns.service`: 

```ini
[Unit]
Description=NextDNS DNS53 to DoH proxy.
ConditionFileIsExecutable=/usr/bin/nextdns
After=network.target
Before=nss-lookup.target
Wants=nss-lookup.target

[Service]
StartLimitInterval=5
StartLimitBurst=10
Environment=SERVICE_RUN_MODE=1
ExecStart=/usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
RestartSec=120
LimitMEMLOCK=infinity

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```
```sh
$ ps aux | grep root | grep nextdns
root      543523  0.0  0.6 711800 12712 ?        Ssl  13:49   0:01 /usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```

But when I run: `sudo nextdns config list` to see the config, the `cache-size` didn't show up, `max-inflight-requests` and `report-client-info` is different:

```
discovery-dns 
use-hosts true
listen localhost:53
config /opt/nextdns/config
log-queries false
cache-size 0
cache-max-age 0s
setup-router false
timeout 5s
max-ttl 0s
report-client-info false
mdns all
max-inflight-requests 256
auto-activate false
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
detect-captive-portals false
hardened-privacy false
bogus-priv true
```

It's a little bit odd that the displayed config doesn't match the running config. Looks like NextDNS client maintained another config file, and then let the specified config file to overwrite it? Could be messy when debugging, because you need to check two places for the configs and consider the overwrite by yoruself.

comment.body: That would be welcomed, thanks for proposing.

comment.body:
Sorry I got confused between --config and --config-file. In your case the install is probably editing an existing config, so you get a merge of your --configs with you added previously. Would that make sense?

My advise would be to use `sudo nextdns config edit` and make sure you only keep the lines you want.

Does it make sense?

issue.title: `nextdns config list` didn't exactly match the running config, when using config file
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.10
 - Platform: Ubuntu 20.04.4 LTS with kernel 5.4.0-105-generic

**Problem:** NextDNS cli client didn't show the config file as expected. The config ID and other configs are specified in the config file, but `nextdns config list` didn't see it.

The NextDNS client was installed via the Debian Based Distribution Manual Install method mentioned on wiki: 
- https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/wiki/Debian-Based-Distribution#manual-install


The NextDNS service was installed by the command:

```sh
sudo nextdns install -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```


The content of `/opt/nextdns/config` is actually the result from a previous config, dump via the command `sudo nextdns config list`(the config ID was replaced by `xxxxxx`):
```
discovery-dns 
max-inflight-requests 512
auto-activate false
mdns all
detect-captive-portals false
bogus-priv true
use-hosts false
timeout 5s
listen localhost:53
log-queries false
report-client-info true
hardened-privacy false
config xxxxxx
max-ttl 0s
setup-router true
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
```

The additional manual setting here is: `cache-size 10MB`

I can confirmed that the option `-config-file /opt/nextdns/config` is set in the service file, andhe process is also running with the parameter::

`$ cat /etc/systemd/system/nextdns.service`: 

```ini
[Unit]
Description=NextDNS DNS53 to DoH proxy.
ConditionFileIsExecutable=/usr/bin/nextdns
After=network.target
Before=nss-lookup.target
Wants=nss-lookup.target

[Service]
StartLimitInterval=5
StartLimitBurst=10
Environment=SERVICE_RUN_MODE=1
ExecStart=/usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
RestartSec=120
LimitMEMLOCK=infinity

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```
```sh
$ ps aux | grep root | grep nextdns
root      543523  0.0  0.6 711800 12712 ?        Ssl  13:49   0:01 /usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```

But when I run: `sudo nextdns config list` to see the config, the `cache-size` didn't show up, `max-inflight-requests` and `report-client-info` is different:

```
discovery-dns 
use-hosts true
listen localhost:53
config /opt/nextdns/config
log-queries false
cache-size 0
cache-max-age 0s
setup-router false
timeout 5s
max-ttl 0s
report-client-info false
mdns all
max-inflight-requests 256
auto-activate false
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
detect-captive-portals false
hardened-privacy false
bogus-priv true
```

It's a little bit odd that the displayed config doesn't match the running config. Looks like NextDNS client maintained another config file, and then let the specified config file to overwrite it? Could be messy when debugging, because you need to check two places for the configs and consider the overwrite by yoruself.

comment.body: You are installing with a custom configuration path parameter (`-config`) but then reading the default path (by not providing the same `-config` parameter). I hope it make sense.

issue.title: Allow devices to use multiple configurations
issue.body: One of the things I miss about pihole is that you could have a common set of rules, devices can be assigned to those rules, and you could have another set of rules that the same device could belong to at the same time. This allowed some base functionality for all devices while adding "extra" stuff for specific devices.

issue.title: ipv6 disable but nextdns still listening?
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.38.0
 - Platform: void linux

I have disabled IPv6 on my system. Nextdns config:
```
config xxxxxx
discovery-dns
detect-captive-portals false
listen 0.0.0.0:53
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
log-queries true
hardened-privacy false
use-hosts true
auto-activate true
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
report-client-info true
mdns all
max-inflight-requests 256
max-ttl 5s
bogus-priv true
timeout 5s
setup-router true
```
(note: I specified `0.0.0.0` as the listen address as part of troubleshooting.)

`netstat -anop` shows
```
Active Internet connections (servers and established)
Proto Recv-Q Send-Q Local Address           Foreign Address         State       PID/Program name     Timer
tcp        0      0 192.168.1.102:38596     170.39.224.134:443      ESTABLISHED 269/nextdns          keepalive (9.78/0/0)
tcp6       0      0 :::53                   :::*                    LISTEN      269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
udp        0      0 0.0.0.0:5353            0.0.0.0:*                           269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
udp6       0      0 :::53                   :::*                                269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
udp6       0      0 :::5353                 :::*                                269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
````

Is there a way to get nextdns to stop binding to (nonexistent) ipv6?

`ip a`:
```
1: lo: <LOOPBACK,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 65536 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN group default qlen 1000
    link/loopback 00:00:00:00:00:00 brd 00:00:00:00:00:00
    inet 127.0.0.1/8 scope host lo
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
113: eth0@if114: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc noqueue state UP group default qlen 1000
    link/ether 00:16:3e:44:9b:a4 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff link-netnsid 0
    inet 192.168.1.102/24 brd 192.168.1.255 scope global eth0
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
```

comment.body: Yes, setup-router will ignore the provided listen directive and use a value appropriate for the detected router. I missed that you had that on.

issue.title: NextDNS CLI on Home Assistant!
issue.body:
Hello there!
Is there any way to implement nextdns-cli as Addon for Home Assistant?
This could be very useful for devices using Home Assistant OS, where it's not possible to install other programs.
As far as I know, the competitor AdGuard Home does provide an Addon for Home Assistant but this, configured for NextDNS, won't identify the devices on My NextDNS website.
Cheers!

issue.title: Add Prehook and Pretimestamp features: this allows "time" key come first
issue.body:
Multiple log files can be sorted with `sort` if "time" key comes first.
For example:

```
$ cat node1.log nod2.log node3.log | sort
{"time":"2022-08-06T08:02:01Z","level":"info","node":"node1","message":"foo"}
{"time":"2022-08-06T08:02:12Z","level":"info","node":"node2","message":"bar"}
{"time":"2022-08-06T08:03:03Z","level":"info","node":"node1","message":"bar"}
{"time":"2022-08-06T08:03:10Z","level":"info","node":"node3","message":"bar"}
...
```

It would be useful in environments where logs aren't managed with log managing systems like Google Cloud Logging, AWS CloudWatch, and so on.


What I did:

* I added `Prehook()` feature. It calls hooks just before "level" is added to the buffer.
* I added `Pretimestamp()` feature. It adds timestamp hook with `Prehook`.

comment.body: I'm not comfortable adding such complexity just for field ordering. I would recommend using tools to read JSON logs instead of dealing with raw output.

issue.title: bogus-priv true returning SERVFAIL instead of NXDOMAIN causing pfSense DHCP leases page to hang
issue.body:
I have NextDNS CLI installed on my pfSense firewall, with Unbound resolver configured on an alternate port and discovery-dns and local forwarder configuration for my split-DNS domain pointing at that local Unbound instance. 

When activating NextDNS for answering local queries from pfSense itself, I noticed that the DHCP Leases page in the admin interface was hanging. I ultimately determined that this was being caused by retries on reverse DNS lookups of local IPs that were failing with a SERVFAIL response. If bogus-priv is set to false, then those reverse lookups that are not answered by local Unbound are forwarded up to NextDNS upstream but they now return an NXDOMAIN response as expected. 

The only other changes I've made from defaults that may be somewhat unique is that I've disabled mdns support as NextDNS's mdns client conflicts with the local Avahi instance I use for mdns reflection between subnets. I've also disabled use-hosts as that was returning duplicate A record responses when local unbound and hosts file both contain an entry (pfSense puts all local host overrides both in the /etc/hosts file and in the local Unbound config as local-data entries). use-hosts was also not allowing AAAA queries for entries in /etc/hosts to fall through to DNS upstream or local Unbound via the forwarder entry. (I have unbound set up with "typetransparent" zone type to enable exactly this behavior).

**NextDNS version: 1.37.11**

Redacted config:

```
hardened-privacy false
bogus-priv false
use-hosts false
max-inflight-requests 256
setup-router false
forwarder redacted-domain.com.=127.0.0.1:5555
log-queries false
discovery-dns 127.0.0.1:5555
mdns disabled
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
config 10.70.6.0/23=GUEST-CONFIG-ID
config MAIN-CONFIG-ID
max-ttl 5s
report-client-info true
timeout 5s
auto-activate true
listen 0.0.0.0:53
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
detect-captive-portals false
```

Demonstrating the issue:

With bogus-priv set to false:

```
: dig @127.0.0.1 -x 10.10.10.10

; <<>> DiG 9.16.26 <<>> @127.0.0.1 -x 10.10.10.10
; (1 server found)
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NXDOMAIN, id: 36858
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 0, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 1

;; OPT PSEUDOSECTION:
; EDNS: version: 0, flags:; udp: 1232
;; QUESTION SECTION:
;10.10.10.10.in-addr.arpa.	IN	PTR

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
10.in-addr.arpa.	5	IN	SOA	prisoner.iana.org. hostmaster.root-servers.org. 1 604800 60 604800 604800

;; Query time: 5 msec
;; SERVER: 127.0.0.1#53(127.0.0.1)
;; WHEN: Sun Oct 30 18:09:54 EDT 2022
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 130
```

bogus-priv set to true

```
: dig @127.0.0.1 -x 10.10.10.10

; <<>> DiG 9.16.26 <<>> @127.0.0.1 -x 10.10.10.10
; (1 server found)
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: SERVFAIL, id: 44584
;; flags: qr; QUERY: 0, ANSWER: 0, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; Query time: 0 msec
;; SERVER: 127.0.0.1#53(127.0.0.1)
;; WHEN: Sun Oct 30 18:10:50 EDT 2022
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 12
```

Nov 11 13:19:51.738295 WARN ...

pull_request.title: Add global ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField to reverse stack and error order
pull_request.body:
Stacktrace is enabled, and the output gets like this:

```
{"level":"error","stack":[{"func":"inner","line":"20","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"middle","line":"24","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"outer","line":"32","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"15","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"204","source":"proc.go"},{"func":"goexit","line":"1374","source":"asm_amd64.s"}],"error":"seems we have an error here","time":1609086683}
```

`"stack"` is often long and `"error"` comes to the later part of the log line.
I have difficulties for this behavior when using with datadog (https://www.datadoghq.com/): datadog sends error logs to monitoring devices (like mobile phone), but those logs are truncated with the beginning part of logs. Those logs are filled with stacktrace and I cannot see the most important "error" field there.

This pull request introduces `zerolog.ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField`.
Setting `zerolog.ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField = true` results log output like this:
```
{"level":"error","error":"seems we have an error here","stack":[{"func":"inner","line":"20","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"middle","line":"24","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"outer","line":"32","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"15","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"204","source":"proc.go"},{"func":"goexit","line":"1374","source":"asm_amd64.s"}],"time":1609086683}
```
You can find the error message easily.

issue.title: Feature Request: Session Support
issue.body:
`curl` allows users to support cookie based sessions with the `--cookie-jar` and `--cookie` flags.

`httpie` has similar functionality with the `--session` flag.

Are there any plans to add similar functionality with `curlie`?

If there is already a way to do this (since `curlie` is a wrapper around `curl`), I'm not seeing a way to do this in the docs.

issue.title: Invalid condition in WithContext method.
issue.body:
Since non-pointer receivers are passed **_by value_**, once the receiver for `WithContext` was reverted to a non-pointer, [this condition](https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/89617ff99b2feb29ab2d8b6258fac9d671073792/ctx.go#L30) is guaranteed to always be false.

In other words, the receiver (`l`) is a _copy_ of the Logger struct from the caller and its address can never be the same as the logger attached to the `Context`. 

Either the receiver should be converted back to a pointer (and different fixes devised for #116 and #400) -- or, this condition should simply be removed and the docs updated to say that the Context will always be replaced no matter what (because that's the actual behavior with the current logic).

[Here's a [Go Playground link](https://go.dev/play/p/Abw-heqUhwP) proving that non-pointer receivers have different addresses from those of their caller]

pull_request.title: Fix docs and behavior of WithContext
pull_request.body:
This change updates `WithContext` to better match documented behavior and also updates the documentation to both clarify existing behavior as well as the behavior expected by existing tests.

Note: since `WithContext` no longer employs a pointer receiver, the value comparison against the Context's attached logger value must be done via `reflect.DeepEqual`.

Fixes: #498

commits.message:
ConsoleWriter fallbacks to local timezone for missing TZ indicator (#497)

Closes issue #483

Before:
We use time.Parse which defaults to TZ UTC if there is no time zone
indicator specified in the time layout string. During the reparsing in
ConsoleWriter we therefore added the TZ difference to UTC twice.

After:
We use time.ParseInLocal where we need to provide a dedicated fallback
TZ as a fallback. Since we now fallback to the local TZ, we don't add
the TZ difference to UTC twice.

pull_request.title: ConsoleWriter fallbacks to local timezone for missing TZ indicator
pull_request.body:
Closes issue #483

Before:
We use time.Parse which defaults to TZ UTC if there is no time zone indicator specified in the time layout string. During the reparsing in ConsoleWriter we therefore added the TZ difference to UTC twice.

After:
We use time.ParseInLocal where we need to provide a dedicated fallback TZ as a fallback. Since we now fallback to the local TZ, we don't add the TZ difference to UTC twice.

issue.title: The time value is wrong when outputting the log to console.
issue.body:
**Code**：

```
package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"os"
	"time"

	"github.com/rs/zerolog"
	"github.com/rs/zerolog/log"
)

func main() {
	timeFormat := "2006-01-02 15:04:05"

	t := time.Now()
	fmt.Print("local zone: ")
	fmt.Println(t.Local().Zone())
	fmt.Println("def:", t.Format(timeFormat))
	fmt.Println("loc:", t.Local().Format(timeFormat))
	fmt.Println("utc:", t.UTC().Format(timeFormat))

	zerolog.TimeFieldFormat = timeFormat
	log.Print("hello world")

	log.Logger = log.Output(zerolog.ConsoleWriter{Out: os.Stderr, TimeFormat: timeFormat})
	log.Info().Msg("Wrong time")
}
```


**Output**:

> local zone: CST 28800
> def: 2022-09-23 21:19:29
> loc: 2022-09-23 21:19:29
> utc: 2022-09-23 13:19:29
> {"level":"debug","time":"2022-09-23 21:19:29","message":"hello world"}
> **2022-09-24 05:19:29** INF Wrong time

The local time is **2022-09-23 21:19:29** and the UTC time is **2022-09-23 13:19:29**, but the console output time is **2022-09-24 05:19:29** .
This issue is caused by #415 .

comment.body: I'm fine with a local tz default on console writer.

commits.message:
Adding Event.Type(...) method to log the type of an object (#437)

Co-authored-by: Mario Cormier <mcormier@rossvideo.com>

pull_request.title: Adding Event.Type(...) method to log the type of an object
pull_request.body:
I found myself wanting to log the type of an object and was convinced there would be a method to do that already, but I didn't find one.  Here's a case where one might want such a method:

```go
	var value interface{}
	var result string
	switch v := value.(type) {
	case int:
		result = strconv.Itoa(v)
	case string:
		result = v
	default:
		log.Panic().Type("type", v).Msg("Unexpected value type")
	}
	log.Info().Msg(result)
```

Let me know if there's anything else that needs to change for this to get accepted.

issue.title: nextdns stops running often
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.11
 - Platform: Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS 4.15.0-70-generic  

**Description**

I have a bash script (https://github.com/mbierman/Firewalla-NextDNS-CLI-install/blob/main/nextdnstest.sh) I run every 5 minutes to make sure that nextdns is installed and running using

```sudo nextdns status ```

If status is not, "running" then  it restarts nextdns and 15 seconds later it tries again. Most of the time that keeps things running without much noticeably wrong.  But it seems like one shouldn't have to be checking this often.

As you can see in the attached log, many times a day it fails. The number of tries listed shows how many loops required before nextdns reports "running" 

Other users are seeing similar things as covered in [this forum post](https://help.nextdns.io/t/g9h78dq/lot-of-disconnections-nextdns-cli-has-to-be-reinstalled-every-2-days). 

[nextdns.log](https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/files/9671612/nextdns.log)

comment.body: What do you get in `journalctl -ef` while this happen?

comment.body: From those logs we can only see that systemd is the one stopping and restarting the nextdns server. It is hard to tell from there what is making systemd doing that. Could be some maintenance cronjobs from firewalla, but I don't see why something would do that. More complete systemd logs could help understand what is going one perhaps.

issue.title: nextdns stops running often
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.11
 - Platform: Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS 4.15.0-70-generic  

**Description**

I have a bash script (https://github.com/mbierman/Firewalla-NextDNS-CLI-install/blob/main/nextdnstest.sh) I run every 5 minutes to make sure that nextdns is installed and running using

```sudo nextdns status ```

If status is not, "running" then  it restarts nextdns and 15 seconds later it tries again. Most of the time that keeps things running without much noticeably wrong.  But it seems like one shouldn't have to be checking this often.

The NextDNS client was installed via the Debian Based Distribution Manual Install method mentioned on wiki:

The NextDNS service was installed by the command:

```sh
sudo nextdns install -config-file /opt/nextdns/config

The content of `/opt/nextdns/config` is actually the result from a previous config, dump via the command `sudo nextdns config list`(the config ID was replaced by `xxxxxx`):
```
discovery-dns 
max-inflight-requests 512
auto-activate false
mdns all
detect-captive-portals false
bogus-priv true
use-hosts false
timeout 5s
listen localhost:53
log-queries false
report-client-info true
hardened-privacy false
config xxxxxx
max-ttl 0s
setup-router true
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s

The additional manual setting here is: `cache-size 10MB`

I can confirmed that the option `-config-file /opt/nextdns/config` is set in the service file, andhe process is also running with the parameter::

`$ cat /etc/systemd/system/nextdns.service`: 

```ini
[Unit]
Description=NextDNS DNS53 to DoH proxy.
ConditionFileIsExecutable=/usr/bin/nextdns

issue.title: Allow devices to use multiple configurations
issue.body: One of the things I miss about pihole is that you could have a common set of rules, devices can be assigned to those rules, and you could have another set of rules that the same device could belong to at the same time. This allowed some base functionality for all devices while adding "extra" stuff for specific devices.

issue.title: ipv6 disable but nextdns still listening?
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.38.0
 - Platform: void linux

I have disabled IPv6 on my system. Nextdns config:
```
config xxxxxx
discovery-dns
detect-captive-portals false
listen 0.0.0.0:53
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
log-queries true
hardened-privacy false
use-hosts true
auto-activate true
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
report-client-info true
mdns all
max-inflight-requests 256
max-ttl 5s
bogus-priv true
timeout 5s
setup-router true
```
(note: I specified `0.0.0.0` as the listen address as part of troubleshooting.)

`netstat -anop` shows
```
Active Internet connections (servers and established)
Proto Recv-Q Send-Q Local Address           Foreign Address         State       PID/Program name     Timer
tcp        0      0 192.168.1.102:38596     170.39.224.134:443      ESTABLISHED 269/nextdns          keepalive (9.78/0/0)
tcp6       0      0 :::53                   :::*                    LISTEN      269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
udp        0      0 0.0.0.0:5353            0.0.0.0:*                           269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
udp6       0      0 :::53                   :::*                                269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
udp6       0      0 :::5353                 :::*                                269/nextdns          off (0.00/0/0)
````

Is there a way to get nextdns to stop binding to (nonexistent) ipv6?

`ip a`:
```
1: lo: <LOOPBACK,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 65536 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN group default qlen 1000
    link/loopback 00:00:00:00:00:00 brd 00:00:00:00:00:00
    inet 127.0.0.1/8 scope host lo
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
113: eth0@if114: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc noqueue state UP group default qlen 1000
    link/ether 00:16:3e:44:9b:a4 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff link-netnsid 0
    inet 192.168.1.102/24 brd 192.168.1.255 scope global eth0
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
```

comment.body: Yes, setup-router will ignore the provided listen directive and use a value appropriate for the detected router. I missed that you had that on.

issue.title: NextDNS CLI on Home Assistant!
issue.body:
Hello there!
Is there any way to implement nextdns-cli as Addon for Home Assistant?
This could be very useful for devices using Home Assistant OS, where it's not possible to install other programs.
As far as I know, the competitor AdGuard Home does provide an Addon for Home Assistant but this, configured for NextDNS, won't identify the devices on My NextDNS website.
Cheers!

issue.title: Add Prehook and Pretimestamp features: this allows "time" key come first
issue.body:
Multiple log files can be sorted with `sort` if "time" key comes first.
For example:

```
$ cat node1.log nod2.log node3.log | sort
{"time":"2022-08-06T08:02:01Z","level":"info","node":"node1","message":"foo"}
{"time":"2022-08-06T08:02:12Z","level":"info","node":"node2","message":"bar"}
{"time":"2022-08-06T08:03:03Z","level":"info","node":"node1","message":"bar"}
{"time":"2022-08-06T08:03:10Z","level":"info","node":"node3","message":"bar"}
...
```

It would be useful in environments where logs aren't managed with log managing systems like Google Cloud Logging, AWS CloudWatch, and so on.


What I did:

* I added `Prehook()` feature. It calls hooks just before "level" is added to the buffer.
* I added `Pretimestamp()` feature. It adds timestamp hook with `Prehook`.

comment.body: I'm not comfortable adding such complexity just for field ordering. I would recommend using tools to read JSON logs instead of dealing with raw output.

issue.title: bogus-priv true returning SERVFAIL instead of NXDOMAIN causing pfSense DHCP leases page to hang
issue.body:
I have NextDNS CLI installed on my pfSense firewall, with Unbound resolver configured on an alternate port and discovery-dns and local forwarder configuration for my split-DNS domain pointing at that local Unbound instance. 

When activating NextDNS for answering local queries from pfSense itself, I noticed that the DHCP Leases page in the admin interface was hanging. I ultimately determined that this was being caused by retries on reverse DNS lookups of local IPs that were failing with a SERVFAIL response. If bogus-priv is set to false, then those reverse lookups that are not answered by local Unbound are forwarded up to NextDNS upstream but they now return an NXDOMAIN response as expected. 

The only other changes I've made from defaults that may be somewhat unique is that I've disabled mdns support as NextDNS's mdns client conflicts with the local Avahi instance I use for mdns reflection between subnets. I've also disabled use-hosts as that was returning duplicate A record responses when local unbound and hosts file both contain an entry (pfSense puts all local host overrides both in the /etc/hosts file and in the local Unbound config as local-data entries). use-hosts was also not allowing AAAA queries for entries in /etc/hosts to fall through to DNS upstream or local Unbound via the forwarder entry. (I have unbound set up with "typetransparent" zone type to enable exactly this behavior).

**NextDNS version: 1.37.11**

Redacted config:

```
hardened-privacy false
bogus-priv false
use-hosts false
max-inflight-requests 256
setup-router false
forwarder redacted-domain.com.=127.0.0.1:5555
log-queries false
discovery-dns 127.0.0.1:5555
mdns disabled
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
config 10.70.6.0/23=GUEST-CONFIG-ID
config MAIN-CONFIG-ID
max-ttl 5s
report-client-info true
timeout 5s
auto-activate true
listen 0.0.0.0:53
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
detect-captive-portals false
```

Demonstrating the issue:

With bogus-priv set to false:

```
: dig @127.0.0.1 -x 10.10.10.10

; <<>> DiG 9.16.26 <<>> @127.0.0.1 -x 10.10.10.10
; (1 server found)
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NXDOMAIN, id: 36858
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 0, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 1

;; OPT PSEUDOSECTION:
; EDNS: version: 0, flags:; udp: 1232
;; QUESTION SECTION:
;10.10.10.10.in-addr.arpa.	IN	PTR

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
10.in-addr.arpa.	5	IN	SOA	prisoner.iana.org. hostmaster.root-servers.org. 1 604800 60 604800 604800

;; Query time: 5 msec
;; SERVER: 127.0.0.1#53(127.0.0.1)
;; WHEN: Sun Oct 30 18:09:54 EDT 2022
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 130
```

bogus-priv set to true

```
: dig @127.0.0.1 -x 10.10.10.10

; <<>> DiG 9.16.26 <<>> @127.0.0.1 -x 10.10.10.10
; (1 server found)
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: SERVFAIL, id: 44584
;; flags: qr; QUERY: 0, ANSWER: 0, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; Query time: 0 msec
;; SERVER: 127.0.0.1#53(127.0.0.1)
;; WHEN: Sun Oct 30 18:10:50 EDT 2022
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 12
```

pull_request.title: parsing CAPS log levels
pull_request.body:
Really tiny improvement that makes life better. Sometimes people use caps log levels, like INFO, WARN, etc. And it also makes sense, because in logs zerolog actually writes things like
```
Nov 11 13:19:51.738295 WARN ...
```
So, it can be not obvious that it will not parse WARN log level.

pull_request.title: Add global ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField to reverse stack and error order
pull_request.body:
Stacktrace is enabled, and the output gets like this:

```
{"level":"error","stack":[{"func":"inner","line":"20","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"middle","line":"24","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"outer","line":"32","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"15","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"204","source":"proc.go"},{"func":"goexit","line":"1374","source":"asm_amd64.s"}],"error":"seems we have an error here","time":1609086683}
```

`"stack"` is often long and `"error"` comes to the later part of the log line.
I have difficulties for this behavior when using with datadog (https://www.datadoghq.com/): datadog sends error logs to monitoring devices (like mobile phone), but those logs are truncated with the beginning part of logs. Those logs are filled with stacktrace and I cannot see the most important "error" field there.

This pull request introduces `zerolog.ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField`.
Setting `zerolog.ErrorStackFieldAfterErrorField = true` results log output like this:
```
{"level":"error","error":"seems we have an error here","stack":[{"func":"inner","line":"20","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"middle","line":"24","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"outer","line":"32","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"15","source":"errors.go"},{"func":"main","line":"204","source":"proc.go"},{"func":"goexit","line":"1374","source":"asm_amd64.s"}],"time":1609086683}
```
You can find the error message easily.

issue.title: Feature Request: Session Support
issue.body:
`curl` allows users to support cookie based sessions with the `--cookie-jar` and `--cookie` flags.

`httpie` has similar functionality with the `--session` flag.

Are there any plans to add similar functionality with `curlie`?

If there is already a way to do this (since `curlie` is a wrapper around `curl`), I'm not seeing a way to do this in the docs.

comment.body: Just pass it, there is nothing special to do.

commits.message: Fix docs and behavior of WithContext (#499)

issue.title: Invalid condition in WithContext method.
issue.body:
Since non-pointer receivers are passed **_by value_**, once the receiver for `WithContext` was reverted to a non-pointer, [this condition](https://github.com/rs/zerolog/blob/89617ff99b2feb29ab2d8b6258fac9d671073792/ctx.go#L30) is guaranteed to always be false.

In other words, the receiver (`l`) is a _copy_ of the Logger struct from the caller and its address can never be the same as the logger attached to the `Context`. 

Either the receiver should be converted back to a pointer (and different fixes devised for #116 and #400) -- or, this condition should simply be removed and the docs updated to say that the Context will always be replaced no matter what (because that's the actual behavior with the current logic).

[Here's a [Go Playground link](https://go.dev/play/p/Abw-heqUhwP) proving that non-pointer receivers have different addresses from those of their caller]

pull_request.title: Fix docs and behavior of WithContext
pull_request.body:
This change updates `WithContext` to better match documented behavior and also updates the documentation to both clarify existing behavior as well as the behavior expected by existing tests.

Note: since `WithContext` no longer employs a pointer receiver, the value comparison against the Context's attached logger value must be done via `reflect.DeepEqual`.

Fixes: #498

In other words, the receiver (`l`) is a _copy_ of the Logger struct from the caller and its address can never be the same as the logger attached to the `Context`. 

Either the receiver should be converted back to a pointer (and different fixes devised for #116 and #400) -- or, this condition should simply be removed and the docs updated to say that the Context will always be replaced no matter what (because that's the actual behavior with the current logic).

[Here's a [Go Playground link](https://go.dev/play/p/Abw-heqUhwP) proving that non-pointer receivers have different addresses from those of their caller]

comment.body: Ok, I'll prefer removing the condition then.

commits.message:
ConsoleWriter fallbacks to local timezone for missing TZ indicator (#497)

Closes issue #483

Before:
We use time.Parse which defaults to TZ UTC if there is no time zone
indicator specified in the time layout string. During the reparsing in
ConsoleWriter we therefore added the TZ difference to UTC twice.

After:
We use time.ParseInLocal where we need to provide a dedicated fallback
TZ as a fallback. Since we now fallback to the local TZ, we don't add
the TZ difference to UTC twice.

pull_request.title: ConsoleWriter fallbacks to local timezone for missing TZ indicator
pull_request.body:
Closes issue #483

Before:
We use time.Parse which defaults to TZ UTC if there is no time zone indicator specified in the time layout string. During the reparsing in ConsoleWriter we therefore added the TZ difference to UTC twice.

After:
We use time.ParseInLocal where we need to provide a dedicated fallback TZ as a fallback. Since we now fallback to the local TZ, we don't add the TZ difference to UTC twice.

issue.title: The time value is wrong when outputting the log to console.
issue.body:
**Code**：

```
package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"os"
	"time"

	"github.com/rs/zerolog"
	"github.com/rs/zerolog/log"
)

func main() {
	timeFormat := "2006-01-02 15:04:05"

	t := time.Now()
	fmt.Print("local zone: ")
	fmt.Println(t.Local().Zone())
	fmt.Println("def:", t.Format(timeFormat))
	fmt.Println("loc:", t.Local().Format(timeFormat))
	fmt.Println("utc:", t.UTC().Format(timeFormat))

	zerolog.TimeFieldFormat = timeFormat
	log.Print("hello world")

	log.Logger = log.Output(zerolog.ConsoleWriter{Out: os.Stderr, TimeFormat: timeFormat})
	log.Info().Msg("Wrong time")
}
```


**Output**:

> local zone: CST 28800
> def: 2022-09-23 21:19:29
> loc: 2022-09-23 21:19:29
> utc: 2022-09-23 13:19:29
> {"level":"debug","time":"2022-09-23 21:19:29","message":"hello world"}
> **2022-09-24 05:19:29** INF Wrong time

The local time is **2022-09-23 21:19:29** and the UTC time is **2022-09-23 13:19:29**, but the console output time is **2022-09-24 05:19:29** .
This issue is caused by #415 .

comment.body: I'm fine with a local tz default on console writer.

commits.message:
Adding Event.Type(...) method to log the type of an object (#437)

Co-authored-by: Mario Cormier <mcormier@rossvideo.com>

pull_request.title: Adding Event.Type(...) method to log the type of an object
pull_request.body:
I found myself wanting to log the type of an object and was convinced there would be a method to do that already, but I didn't find one.  Here's a case where one might want such a method:

```go
	var value interface{}
	var result string
	switch v := value.(type) {
	case int:
		result = strconv.Itoa(v)
	case string:
		result = v
	default:
		log.Panic().Type("type", v).Msg("Unexpected value type")
	}
	log.Info().Msg(result)
```

Let me know if there's anything else that needs to change for this to get accepted.

issue.title: nextdns stops running often
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.11
 - Platform: Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS 4.15.0-70-generic  

**Description**

I have a bash script (https://github.com/mbierman/Firewalla-NextDNS-CLI-install/blob/main/nextdnstest.sh) I run every 5 minutes to make sure that nextdns is installed and running using

```sudo nextdns status ```

If status is not, "running" then  it restarts nextdns and 15 seconds later it tries again. Most of the time that keeps things running without much noticeably wrong.  But it seems like one shouldn't have to be checking this often.

As you can see in the attached log, many times a day it fails. The number of tries listed shows how many loops required before nextdns reports "running" 

Other users are seeing similar things as covered in [this forum post](https://help.nextdns.io/t/g9h78dq/lot-of-disconnections-nextdns-cli-has-to-be-reinstalled-every-2-days). 

[nextdns.log](https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/files/9671612/nextdns.log)

comment.body: What do you get in `journalctl -ef` while this happen?

issue.title: `nextdns config list` didn't exactly match the running config, when using config file
issue.body:
**Context**
 - CLI Version: 1.37.10
 - Platform: Ubuntu 20.04.4 LTS with kernel 5.4.0-105-generic

**Problem:** NextDNS cli client didn't show the config file as expected. The config ID and other configs are specified in the config file, but `nextdns config list` didn't see it.

The NextDNS client was installed via the Debian Based Distribution Manual Install method mentioned on wiki: 
- https://github.com/nextdns/nextdns/wiki/Debian-Based-Distribution#manual-install


The NextDNS service was installed by the command:

```sh
sudo nextdns install -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```


The content of `/opt/nextdns/config` is actually the result from a previous config, dump via the command `sudo nextdns config list`(the config ID was replaced by `xxxxxx`):
```
discovery-dns 
max-inflight-requests 512
auto-activate false
mdns all
detect-captive-portals false
bogus-priv true
use-hosts false
timeout 5s
listen localhost:53
log-queries false
report-client-info true
hardened-privacy false
config xxxxxx
max-ttl 0s
setup-router true
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
cache-size 10MB
cache-max-age 0s
```

The additional manual setting here is: `cache-size 10MB`

I can confirmed that the option `-config-file /opt/nextdns/config` is set in the service file, andhe process is also running with the parameter::

`$ cat /etc/systemd/system/nextdns.service`: 

```ini
[Unit]
Description=NextDNS DNS53 to DoH proxy.
ConditionFileIsExecutable=/usr/bin/nextdns
After=network.target
Before=nss-lookup.target
Wants=nss-lookup.target

[Service]
StartLimitInterval=5
StartLimitBurst=10
Environment=SERVICE_RUN_MODE=1
ExecStart=/usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
RestartSec=120
LimitMEMLOCK=infinity

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```
```sh
$ ps aux | grep root | grep nextdns
root      543523  0.0  0.6 711800 12712 ?        Ssl  13:49   0:01 /usr/bin/nextdns run -config-file /opt/nextdns/config
```

But when I run: `sudo nextdns config list` to see the config, the `cache-size` didn't show up, `max-inflight-requests` and `report-client-info` is different:

```
discovery-dns 
use-hosts true
listen localhost:53
config /opt/nextdns/config
log-queries false
cache-size 0
cache-max-age 0s
setup-router false
timeout 5s
max-ttl 0s
report-client-info false
mdns all
max-inflight-requests 256
auto-activate false
control /var/run/nextdns.sock
detect-captive-portals false
hardened-privacy false
bogus-priv true
```

It's a little bit odd that the displayed config doesn't match the running config. Looks like NextDNS client maintained another config file, and then let the specified config file to overwrite it? Could be messy when debugging, because you need to check two places for the configs and consider the overwrite by yoruself.

comment.body: That would be welcomed, thanks for proposing.

Sorry I got confused between --config and --config-file. In your case the install is probably editing an existing config, so you get a merge of your --configs with you added previously. Would that make sense?

My advise would be to use `sudo nextdns config edit` and make sure you only keep the lines you want.

Does it make sense?

issue.title: Allow devices to use multiple configurations
issue.body: One of the things I miss about pihole is that you could have a common set of rules, devices can be assigned to those rules, and you could have another set of rules that the same device could belong to at the same time. This allowed some base functionality for all devices while adding "extra" stuff for specific devices.
